Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment is reserved during a limited window when specialized instruments are available.
Story: My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. It was 2:13 a.m. I squinted at the screen—Sam. I answered, and immediately heard sobs. Through broken words, Sam told me about the accident, the hospital, the uncertainty. My heart clenched. I knew what I was supposed to do: listen, comfort, be present. But as I murmured soothing words, my eyes darted to the clock. In less than four hours, I needed to be at the lab. The mass spectrometer, booked months in advance, was finally available for my experiment. If I missed this window, my research would be set back for weeks, maybe months. I tried to focus on Sam’s pain, but my mind kept drifting to calibration protocols and data sheets. I felt torn in two—one part aching to be the friend Sam needed, the other gripped by the pressure of my scientific responsibilities. My hands shook as I held the phone, caught between the urge to stay and the knowledge that I might have to leave.
